questions.text: What is the mean birth weight of Indian babies?
questions.solution:
The mean birth weight of Indian babies is 2.8 kg, slightly lower than Western averages due to genetic and maternal nutritional factors.

  • Birth weight is an important indicator of a newborn's health and a predictor of survival, growth, and development.
  • In India, the average (mean) birth weight is approximately 2.8 kg, which is lower than the global average (~3.1-3.4 kg).
  • Factors influencing this include maternal nutrition, socioeconomic status, maternal health during pregnancy, and genetic predisposition.
  • A birth weight of <2.5 kg is considered low birth weight (LBW), which increases the risk of neonatal morbidity and mortality.
  • Public health programs like Janani Suraksha Yojana and POSHAN Abhiyaan aim to reduce LBW incidence.

questions.text: In the extended definition of perinatal mortality, the crown-heel length is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The extended definition of perinatal mortality includes fetuses/newborns with a crown-heel length > 35 cm, even if the weight or gestational age is unknown.

  • Perinatal mortality refers to fetal deaths (stillbirths) and early neonatal deaths combined.
  • The extended definition was introduced to make classification easier in cases where gestational age or weight may be unknown.
  • WHO standard definition considers:
    • Fetal deaths ≥ 28 weeks of gestation (or ≥ 1000 g birth weight).
  • An extended definition allows identification based on crown-heel length > 35 cm as an alternative criterion, since it correlates with ~28 weeks of gestation.
  • This helps in accurate reporting in rural or resource-limited settings where weighing or dating is difficult.

choices.text: 3rd percentile for girls (lower reference curve)

questions.text: In the Road to Health chart, the uppermost reference line is equivalent to:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The uppermost line in the Road to Health chart corresponds to the median (50th percentile) weight-for-age for boys.

  • The Road to Health chart is a growth monitoring tool used to assess a child's nutritional status over time.
  • It has three main reference curves:
    • Uppermost line:
      • Median (50th percentile) weight-for-age for boys - represents ideal growth.
    • Middle lines:
      • Often drawn at 80% and 70% of the median, marking grades of malnutrition.
    • Lowermost line:
      • 3rd percentile (or ~ -2 SD) weight-for-age -marks severe malnutrition risk.
  • The reason the top line is based on boys' median values is historical - early WHO/NCHS reference data was derived from boys, and separate charts were later developed for girls.
  • Children's growth plotted close to the uppermost line indicates healthy weight-for-age, while progressive downward deviation signals undernutrition.

questions.text: If a newborn's birth weight is 3 kg, by the end of 1 year, it should become:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

By 12 months, an infant's weight is expected to triple the birth weight.

  • Growth during infancy follows a predictable pattern:
    • By 5 months, Birth weight doubles.
    • By 1 year, Birth weight triples.
    • By 2 years, Birth weight quadruples.
  • Therefore, a baby born at 3 kg is expected to weigh:
    • At 5 months → ~6 kg
    • At 1 year → ~9 kg
  • This rapid growth is supported by exclusive breastfeeding for the first 6 months, followed by the introduction of complementary feeding.
  • Deviations from these milestones may indicate growth faltering or nutritional disorders.

questions.text: In the WHO growth chart, the lower percentile represents:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The 3rd percentile in WHO growth charts indicates the lower reference limit for normal growth.

  • WHO growth charts are used to monitor a child's physical growth compared to a healthy reference population.
  • Percentiles indicate the relative position of a child's measurement (weight, height, BMI) among the reference population.
  • The 3rd percentile is considered the lower cutoff-children below this are classified as below normal growth, potentially indicating under-nutrition or growth faltering.
  • The 50th percentile represents the median (average) growth.
  • The 97th percentile is usually the upper cutoff for overweight in BMI charts.
  • In practice:
    • < 3rd percentile: Growth faltering or undernutrition suspected.
    • > 97th percentile: Overnutrition or obesity suspected.

questions.text: A 3.5-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic for a routine check-up. His mother reports that his birth length was 50 cm. On examination, his current height is 95 cm. Which of the following is the expected age at which a child's height should normally double from birth length?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Birth length doubles by 4 years of age in normal growth patterns.

  • At birth, the average length is 50 cm.
  • By 1 year: increases by ~50% → ~75 cm
  • By 4 years: doubles → ~100 cm
  • By adolescence, triples (~150 cm), depending on sex and genetics.
  • Height milestones are important indicators of long-term growth and nutrition status, unlike weight, which is more sensitive to acute illness.
  • A deviation from expected height gain often indicates chronic conditions, endocrine issues, or prolonged malnutrition.

choices.text: Well-nourished and mother should be appreciated
Moderately malnourished and advise mother to improve nourishment
Severe malnutrition and send the child to higher centres
Severe malnutrition and counsel the mother for a high-calorie and nourishing diet

questions.text: A 16-month-old child weighing 8 kg is brought for a routine check-up. On plotting weight-for-age on the WHO growth chart, the child falls below the -2 SD curve but above the -3 SD curve. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnosis and management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Weight-for-age between -2 SD and -3 SD on WHO growth charts indicates moderate undernutrition.

  • WHO growth standards classify nutritional status by Z-scores (SD scores):
    • ≥ -2 SD: Normal
    • < -2 SD to ≥ -3 SD: Moderate underweight (moderate malnutrition)
    • < -3 SD: Severe underweight (severe malnutrition)
  • In this case:
    • 16-month-old expected weight = 10-11 kg (median)
    • Actual weight = 8 kg → falls between -2 SD and -3 SD
    • This signifies moderate malnutrition
  • Management:
    • No hospital admission needed unless complications
    • Provide nutritional counseling to the mother
    • Encourage a high-calorie, high-protein homemade diet
    • Monitor growth monthly
    • Check for associated deficiencies (iron, vitamin A, zinc)

questions.text: What is the most common cause of infant mortality in India?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Low birth weight is the leading cause of infant mortality in India due to its association with prematurity, poor immunity, and a higher risk of infections.

  • Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) is the number of deaths of infants under 1 year per 1,000 live births in a given year.
  • In India, the most common cause of infant mortality is low birth weight (LBW), defined as birth weight < 2.5 kg, irrespective of gestational age.
  • Reasons why LBW leads to high mortality:
    • Increased vulnerability to hypothermia
    • Immature immunity, increasing risk of sepsis and respiratory infections
    • Higher risk of feeding difficulties and hypoglycemia
    • Often associated with prematurity or intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR)
  • In India, factors like maternal malnutrition, anemia, inadequate antenatal care, and adolescent pregnancies contribute significantly to LBW incidence.
  • Public health significance:
    • Reducing LBW is a key goal under the National Health Mission
    • Interventions include improving maternal nutrition, iron-folic acid supplementation, regular ANC, institutional deliveries, and kangaroo mother care.

Explanation of other options:

Respiratory disease (Option B): Incorrect - although respiratory distress is a significant cause of early neonatal mortality, it is less common than LBW-related complications in India.

Diarrhoeal disease (Option C): Incorrect - diarrheal diseases are a leading cause of post-neonatal mortality, but overall, LBW remains the most frequent cause in the first year.

Congenital anomalies (Option D): Incorrect -while congenital malformations contribute to infant mortality, especially in developed countries, in India, their proportion is lower than LBW-related deaths.

questions.text: Which of the following indicators is used for growth monitoring at an Anganwadi centre?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Anganwadi centres under ICDS use weight-for-age as the primary indicator for growth monitoring in children.

  • In India, under the Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) scheme, Anganwadi workers are tasked with monitoring the growth and nutritional status of children under 6 years.
  • The most practical and widely used parameter for this at the community level is weight-for-age, as it is easy to measure, requires minimal equipment (a weighing scale), and can be plotted on growth charts (Road to Health charts) to track progress over time.
  • Why weight-for-age?
    • Simple and low-cost method
    • Reflects both acute and chronic malnutrition
    • Allows early detection of undernutrition so that interventions can be made
  • However, it does not differentiate between acute and chronic malnutrition - for that, other indices like height-for-age or weight-for-height are needed.

Explanation of other options:

Height for age (Option A): Indicates stunting and is used to assess chronic malnutrition, but not the routine indicator used in Anganwadis.

Mid-arm circumference (Option B): A screening tool for severe acute malnutrition, mostly in children 1-5 years, but not used for regular growth monitoring.

Height for weight (Option D): Reflects wasting (acute malnutrition) and is useful in emergency settings, but requires height measurement, which is less feasible in routine Anganwadi work.

questions.text: Which famous paediatrician devised the growth charts for children?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

David Morley, a British paediatrician, developed the growth charts used globally for monitoring child growth and nutritional status.

  • Growth charts are essential tools in paediatrics for assessing a child's growth pattern over time and detecting early signs of malnutrition or disease.
  • David Morley pioneered their development as part of his work on child health in developing countries, particularly in Africa.
  • His charts were adapted to local populations and formed the basis for many national and WHO growth standards.
  • These charts plot parameters such as weight-for-age, height-for-age, and weight-for-height against standard percentiles or Z-scores, allowing clinicians and health workers to detect undernutrition, overnutrition, and growth faltering early.
  • Public health impact:
    • Empowered community health workers to identify malnutrition at the grassroots level
    • Basis for "Road to Health" charts used in under-five clinics

Explanation of other options:

Shanti Ghosh (Option A): Incorrect - an eminent Indian paediatrician known for contributions to child health in India, but not the creator of growth charts.

Derrick Jelliffe (Option B): Incorrect - known for work on maternal and child nutrition, especially human milk and breastfeeding, but not growth chart development.

Nelson (Option C): Incorrect - refers to Waldo E. Nelson, author of Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, but not credited with devising growth charts.

questions.text: Which of the following is the essential criterion for the numerator while calculating the perinatal mortality rate?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

For perinatal mortality rate calculation, the numerator includes stillbirths and early neonatal deaths fulfilling any of the WHO-specified criteria - birth weight ≥1000 g, gestation ≥28 weeks, or crown-heel length ≥35 cm.

  • Perinatal mortality rate (PMR) reflects deaths occurring around the time of birth and is a sensitive indicator of maternal and newborn health services.
  • According to WHO's extended definition, the numerator includes:
    • All stillbirths (fetal deaths) meeting any of the following criteria:
      • Birth weight ≥ 1000 g, or
      • Gestational age ≥ 28 weeks, or
      • Crown-heel length ≥ 35 cm
    • Plus, early neonatal deaths (deaths within 7 completed days of life) meet the same criteria.
  • The denominator is the total number of live births plus stillbirths in the same population and time period.
  • Formula:

PMR = (Stillbirths+Early neonatal deaths(meeting criteria) / Live births+Stillbirths) X 1000

  • This standardization ensures uniform reporting globally, even when accurate gestational dating or weighing is difficult in some settings.

questions.text: The numerator for calculating the child death rate is the number of deaths occurring in children aged:
questions.solution:
Explanationr:

Child death rate measures mortality specifically in children aged 1-4 years, excluding infants.

  • The child death rate (CDR) is a specific mortality rate that reflects the health status and survival of young children after infancy.
  • It is defined as:

CDR = (Number of deaths in children aged 1 - 4 years in a year / Mid-year population of children aged 1 - 4 years) X 1000

  • This indicator helps assess post-infancy child health, the effectiveness of immunization, nutrition programs, and control of infectious diseases.
  • It excludes deaths in children under 1 year (infant mortality) and over 4 years (school-age mortality).
